text: Hello, my SEO people! I have a question here. I had a potential SEO client turn down my services in favor of another agency. The reason was that I "cost too much" and the other agency said they could "do SEO" for less - but this other agency is only changing meta tags and not creating any new content. My strategy involved all the things, from content audit/comp analysis/keyword strategy/content rewrites/and all the other on-page techniques - including updating the metas. My question here is...is there such a thing as just a "metadata strategy" that, on its own can have an incredible impact on your SEO in terms of ranking? I've never heard of offering metas as a standalone service, and I always packaged/completed them as a natural part of SEO keyword/content work...but to offer these just on their own...without any new content/keyword strategy or anything.  Is this a thing? Thoughts?

elements.text: Hello, my SEO people! I have a question here. I had a potential SEO client turn down my services in favor of another agency. My question here is...is there such a thing as just a "metadata strategy" that, on its own can have an incredible impact on your SEO in terms of ranking? I've never heard of offering metas as a standalone service, and I always packaged/completed them as a natural part of SEO keyword/content work...but to offer these just on their own...without any new content/keyword strategy or anything.  Is this a thing? Thoughts?

text: No. Changing title tags and meta descriptions alone will not show a significant lift. You can steal this graphic from my audit deck:

elements.text: No. Changing title tags and meta descriptions alone will not show a significant lift. You can steal this graphic from my audit deck:

It's from an Ahrefs study that they've run twice that shows how meta data compares to backlinks in terms of correlating with rankings.

1. Content
2. Links to the page
3. Links to the overall website
4. Everything else

text: Honestly, you dodged a bullet. If the way they're measuring project success is to hire the cheapest person and spend the least money, then they aren't focused on the outcomes you can provide, anyways.

elements.text: Honestly, you dodged a bullet. If the way they're measuring project success is to hire the cheapest person and spend the least money, then they aren't focused on the outcomes you can provide, anyways.

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> Thanks! I knew they were waffling with my service because they kept asking about the cost. So I wasn't bummed out when they declined. But when I found out they went with someone who is only offering Metas, It was so red-flaggy to me, I wanted to reach out to here.

Trust me, you won't want to work with a client who doesn't understand what you to — it's frustrating.

text: <@U02CVNB3X1T> one thing which could be valuable to you in pitching SEO clients is helping them understand the ROI of investment when pitching, or having it as an initial project for you folks to try out together if you dont wanna do it for free. Think of it as a first date vs committing to a relationship. Folks typically don't want to go with the higher/highest priced option right off the bat, BUT, if you can throw together even a basic projection of ROI based on keywords, positions, click through rate, avg conversion rate, and CLTV... it will more often than not encourage them to invest (if it appears to make financial sense) and if not. It will also better highlight you are skilled at what you do, increasing their trust in you. They could be a great client but are just skittish about investing in this, where there are plenty of folks who unfortunately sell "meta services" as SEO and then people think they invested in SEO and got no return when really they invested in basic website maintenance/refresh.

text:
I pretty much second everything you were told above. Sounds like a cheap company.

My one note would be that if there's any way to educate the client on WHY the other approach is a bad idea, I'd do it. I've converted a few clients just by being able to offer reasonable justifications for why those alternative approaches DON'T work (like <@UUXMCJQ15>’s really awesome graphic above). Depending on how cheap the client is and how willing they are to hear your side, it might turn into something great!

One example: A very successful client we now work with started with us because I sold them on how awful content syndication was and that it was worth the effort to create unique content. They'd been working with a cheap content syndication agency, which obviously produced no results for them. I tripled what they paid on a monthly basis for fewer individual pieces, but they've remained loyal to us and paid more and more over time because the results spoke for themselves.

Again, this client may not at all be an example of that if the cost is the only determining factor for them. But it still speaks to the importance of educating people on what works and what kind of "quick fixes" are just used in the industry to essentially scam people for cash.

Wishing you an AWESOME new client sometime soon who truly values what you're offering! :hearts:

Wishing you an AWESOME new client sometime soon who truly values what you're offering!

text: One thing I do a lot with folks who are just looking to invest in SEO and aren't switching agencies or something where they are already bought in... I offer them a 4 week competitive audit... it examines ROI potential, competitors, their website/content... and at the end i have a great idea of their growth potential, the market, what i can/can't do with them, and can price them options based on their needs... they also get a "trial" with me... and 90% of the time it leads to a 6mo contract... because your findings should end with "how i can help" ha

text:
Ugh, that's so frustrating Julie, I'm sorry! You seem to have been offering a much better, impactful option (I mean, just changing meta descriptions to 'impact seo' - my goodness! I don't think I have enough eyerolls for that one).

When things like that happen, I try to remember this:
• If they go for the 'easier' or 'cheaper' option this is likely to be a red flag. As <@U01TB1SDD61> said, they don't seem to understand what matters as cost seems to be the only thing that sways them.
• They might be back after getting their fingers burned or not seeing the progress they are told they may achieve with the cut price people
I agree with <@U024K88ECFN> that if there's a chance to follow up re value for them for you vs the other agency, it might be worth a try.

text: Oh my gosh! That's horrifying. And I agree — it makes everyone who does this work legitimately look SO bad. Dealing with people who know they need SEO but have been scammed for it before is one of my primary hurdles to overcome every time we sign someone new.

text:
What are you all using to manage your content inventory? I’m looking to see if there’s a software solution that can:
• Maintain a regular crawl of a content hub (blog/resource center/etc)
• Track new URLs added and changes on existing URLs (updates, rewrites, etc)
• Pull in GA/GSC and provide at a glance look at performance stats, keywords, etc per URL.
• Monitor average performance data for each URL and alert when there’s an extreme spike or dip in traffic/impressions.
• Allow assigning of status, tasks, users, and provide automated reminders for reviewing URLs.
• Integration with major project management tools (Asana, ClickUp, Monday, Basecamp, etc)
Have found a couple tools that are more SEO focused monitoring (ContentKing) but not so much on the content marketing/editorial side. Let me know if anyone’s heard of anything that might be worth looking into!

elements.text: What are you all using to manage your content inventory? I’m looking to see if there’s a software solution that can:
Maintain a regular crawl of a content hub (blog/resource center/etc)
Track new URLs added and changes on existing URLs (updates, rewrites, etc)
Pull in GA/GSC and provide at a glance look at performance stats, keywords, etc per URL.
Monitor average performance data for each URL and alert when there’s an extreme spike or dip in traffic/impressions.
Allow assigning of status, tasks, users, and provide automated reminders for reviewing URLs.
Integration with major project management tools (Asana, ClickUp, Monday, Basecamp, etc)

Have found a couple tools that are more SEO focused monitoring (ContentKing) but not so much on the content marketing/editorial side. Let me know if anyone’s heard of anything that might be worth looking into!

text: <@U01881ZL1B6> I really love the 4-week competitive offer. I may just keep this particular client on my AHREFs and see how it pans out for them in 3 months. Curiosity killed the cat?

elements.text: I really love the 4-week competitive offer. I may just keep this particular client on my AHREFs and see how it pans out for them in 3 months. Curiosity killed the cat?

text:
<@U02CVNB3X1T> Keeping tabs on them and reaching back out to ask how things are going is a good sales strategy. Timing is everything in sales and if they realize that they are getting no results from the other agency's work, then they'll be on the lookout for another one to work with.

To <@U01881ZL1B6>'s point, talking about ROI is a very powerful part of the sales process and will often help you stand out in the SEO world where everyone focuses only on traffic and rankings. Talking about ROI is speaking their language rather than making them speak our language. I work with B2B and B2C lead gen companies (think home services, managed IT services, etc) and always ask the following questions:
• What is your AOV (average order value) and CLV (customer lifetime value)?
• What is your CAC (customer acquisition cost) goal?
• what are your leads and sales goals from SEO?
When you ask these questions you accomplish a few things:
1. Identify what kind of client you're dealing with.
2. Position yourself as an authority.
3. Stand out from most other SEOs.
4. Show the client you care that they make money by working with you.
5. Turn the expense of SEO into an investment.
6. Calculate what SEO is worth to them.
7. Set realistic expectations.
1. I find that clients fall into one of a few categories. (1) They've never thought about any of the questions you're asking. This is usually a small business owner and often not the greatest client. You should price accordingly because they will take up more of your time by asking lots of questions and requiring more hand holding. (2) They're a startup and don't have answers because they don't yet have data. If they have previous business experience, they may at least know what you're talking about. (3) The most sophisticated clients, and always the best clients, know their numbers. All else equal, these are the clients you should go above and beyond to close because they are savvy business people who will grow faster and larger than other clients and if you are doing good work for them, they will keep you with them and often increase their budgets with you.

2-5. This is all about the psychology of sales. Years ago I held two different jobs in sales, both in home security. The first was  door to door sales. Anytime I'd knock on a door, I was immediately placed into the "sales person" bucket by the homeowner. Overcoming this perspective was doable, but hard. The homeowner didn't trust me much and thought that anything that came out of my mouth was intended to sell them something. The other job I had was as a home security technician. I would either be installing a home security system or fixing one. When I stepped into a customer's home, making a sale was 10x easier than when I was a door to door rep. One of the biggest reasons for this was because the customer viewed me as an authority on the topic of home security, not as a sales rep. They listened to my suggestions and trusted my advice. When you the  questions above and talk about how the client is going to make money by working with you, you can reposition yourself as the technician instead of the sales rep.

6. When you calculate what SEO is worth to them, it makes your price point more digestible. When a client says they want 10 sales per month from SEO and each sale is worth $1,000 to them, that's $10,000. All of the sudden, your $2,500 price point doesn't seem so bad. For clients who have done SEO and know the value of the channel, this is less important. For those just venturing into SEO seriously, this is an important step.

7. Some clients have wildly unrealistic expectations of ROI or don't know what to expect. By doing the math, you can set realistic expectations.

text:
We built an in-house solution for this, so that won’t be super helpful. MarketMuse has some options for inventory tracking on the enterprise plan (approx. $25K/year) and we use that for the large sites we work on.

Frase has some _basic_ functionality built into their Content Audit tool.

Ahrefs just updated their <https://ahrefs.com/blog/introducing-ahrefs-wp-plugin/|WordPress plugin >and added some decent new features as well you might find useful.

Idk of a single tool that can do all of these things though. Especially one that automatically sends things to major PM tools.

If there’s a large enough demand for it—I can probably work on making a consumer-facing version of the one we built internally.

attachments.fallback: SEO Blog by Ahrefs: Introducing the Ahrefs WP Plugin
attachments.text: The Ahrefs WP plugin shows you how each article on your blog performs for a chosen target keyword based on Ahrefs, GA and GSC data. Then, it suggests what
attachments.title: Introducing the Ahrefs WP Plugin
